summary.long: Job is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: There was a man in the land of Uz whose name was Job. This man was blameless and upright, a man who feared God and turned away from evil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Seven sons and three daughters were born to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His possessions included seven thousand sheep, three thousand camels, five hundred yoke of oxen, and five hundred female donkeys. He also had a very large retinue of servants. This man was the greatest of all the men of the East.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His sons would regularly arrange feasts, each one in his own house on his assigned day, and they would invite their three sisters to eat and drink with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the days of the feast were complete, Job would send for them and consecrate them. Early in the morning he would sacrifice a burnt offering for each of them. Job would say, “Perhaps my children have sinned and cursed God in their hearts.” Job did this regularly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There came a day when the sons of God came to present themselves before the Lord, and Satan also came into their midst.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord said to Satan, “Where have you come from?”
Satan answered the Lord, “From roaming the earth and walking around on it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Satan, “Have you considered my servant Job? There is no one like him on the earth, a man who is blameless and upright, who fears God and turns away from evil.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Satan answered the Lord, “Is it without cause that Job fears God?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You have put a protective hedge around him and his household and everything that belongs to him, haven’t you? You have blessed the work of his hands. His livestock has spread throughout the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But just stretch out your hand and strike everything that is his, and he will certainly curse you to your face!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord said to Satan, “Very well, then. Everything that he has is in your hand. But you may not stretch out your hand against the man himself.” So Satan left the presence of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One day when Job’s sons and daughters were eating and drinking wine in the house of their oldest brother,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: a messenger came to Job and said, “The oxen were plowing and the female donkeys were grazing nearby,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: when the Sabeans swooped down and took them away. They put the servants to death with the sword, and I am the only one who has escaped to tell you!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While he was still speaking, another servant came and said, “The fire of God fell from the sky and burned up the flocks and the servants and consumed them, and I am the only one who has escaped to tell you!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While he was still speaking, another servant came and said, “The Chaldeans formed three raiding parties and plundered the camels and took them away. They put the servants to death with the sword, and I am the only one who has escaped to tell you!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While he was still speaking, another servant came and said, “Your sons and daughters were eating and were drinking wine in the house of their oldest brother.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Suddenly a powerful wind swept in from the wilderness and struck the four corners of the house, and it collapsed on the young people, and they died, and I am the only one who has escaped to tell you!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Job stood up, tore his robe, and shaved his head. He fell to the ground and worshipped.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he said, “Naked I came from my mother’s womb, and naked I will return. The Lord gave and the Lord has taken away. May the name of the Lord be blessed.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In all this, Job did not sin or blame God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Another day arrived when the sons of God came to present themselves before the Lord, and Satan also came into their midst.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord said to Satan, “Where have you come from?”
Satan answered the Lord, “From roaming the earth and walking around on it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Satan, “Have you considered my servant Job? There is no one like him on the earth, a man who is blameless and upright, who fears God and turns away from evil. And he still maintains his integrity, even though you incited me against him to destroy him for no reason.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Satan answered the Lord, “Skin for skin! A man will give all he has for his life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But stretch out your hand and strike his bones and flesh, and he will certainly curse you to your face!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Satan, “Very well, then, he is in your hand, but preserve his life.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Satan then went out from the presence of the Lord. He struck Job with very painful sores from the sole of his foot to the top of his head.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Job took a piece of broken pottery to scrape himself as he was sitting among the ashes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then his wife said to him, “Are you still maintaining your integrity? Curse God and die!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he said to her, “You are talking like a woman who lacks moral judgment. If we accept the good that comes from God, shouldn’t we also accept the bad?” In all this, Job did not sin in what he said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Three friends of Job heard about all this adversity that had come upon him, and each of them came from his own homeland: Eliphaz the Temanite, Bildad the Shuhite, and Zophar the Na’amathite. They met together and went to sympathize with Job and to comfort him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they caught sight of Job from a distance, they did not recognize him. They raised their voices and wept. Each man tore his robe and tossed dust into the air and onto his head.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They sat on the ground with him for seven days and seven nights, but no one spoke a word to him because they saw that his suffering was very great.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Finally, Job opened his lips and cursed the day of his birth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Job spoke up and said:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
May the day of my birth perish,
and the night when it was said, “A child has been conceived!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As for that day, let it be darkness!
May God above have no concern for it.
May light not shine on it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
May darkness and the shadow of death reclaim it.
May a dark cloud settle over it.
May whatever blackens the day terrify it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As for that night, may deep darkness take it away!
May it not be included among the days of the year
or show up in the list of months.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Oh let that night be barren!
May no joyful shout be heard in it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
May those who curse days cast a spell on it,
those who are able to awaken Leviathan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
May its twilight stars be darkened.
May it wait hopefully for light but receive none.
May it never see the eyelids of dawn,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
because it did not shut the doors of my mother’s womb,
and it did not hide trouble from my eyes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why did I not die at birth
or pass away as I came from the womb?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why did my mother’s knees receive me?
Why were her breasts there to nurse me?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For then I would be lying down peacefully.
I would be sleeping and resting quietly
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
with the kings and counselors of the earth,
        with those who rebuilt ruined cities for themselves,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
with high officials who accumulated gold,
        with those who filled their houses with silver.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why was I not hidden like a stillborn child,
like the infants who never see the light of day?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There the wicked cease from turmoil.
There the weary are at rest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There the prisoners are at ease together.
They no longer hear the voice of the slave driver.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There the small and great are alike,
and the slave is free from his master.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why is light given to those weighed down with grief?
Why is life given to those whose spirit is bitter,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
to those who yearn for death but it does not come,
    though they dig for it more than for buried treasure,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
to those who will be thrilled with happiness,
those who will celebrate when they reach the grave?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why is light given to a man whose path is hidden,
to one whom God has hedged in?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Now my sighing takes the place of my daily bread.
My groans gush forth like water,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
because what I feared has overwhelmed me,
and that which I dreaded has come upon me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I have no ease, no quiet, no rest.
Instead, turmoil has come.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Eliphaz the Temanite responded:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If someone ventures to have a word with you, will you grow impatient?
But who can refrain from speaking up?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You yourself have instructed many,
and you have strengthened weak hands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your words have raised up people who were stumbling,
and you have given support to buckling knees.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But now that this has happened to you, you grow impatient.
This strikes you and you are disturbed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Shouldn’t your piety give you confidence?
Don’t your blameless ways give you reason to hope?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Now remember this:
Who has ever perished if he was innocent?
Where were the upright ever erased?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what I have observed:
Those who plow evil and sow trouble will reap the same.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
By the breath of God they perish.
By the blast from his nostrils they come to an end.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The lion roars, and the fierce lion growls,
but the teeth of the young lion are broken.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The strong lion perishes from a lack of prey,
and the cubs of the lioness are scattered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A word was delivered to me secretly.
My ears caught a whisper of it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In the middle of anxious thoughts arising from visions in the night,
at the time when deep sleep falls upon people,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
terror and trembling came over me
and made all my bones tremble.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A spirit passed in front of my face.
The hair on my body stood on end.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A figure stood in front of me,
but I could not tell what it was.
A form stood before my eyes,
and I heard a quiet voice say,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Can a person be righteous before God?
Can a man be pure before his Maker?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If God does not trust his own servants,
if he charges his messengers with error,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
how much more those who dwell in clay houses,
    whose foundations are in the dust,
    who are crushed more quickly than a moth!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
From dawn to dusk they are smashed to pieces.
They perish forever, and no one even notices.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Won’t the ropes that hold up their tents be pulled up,
so that they die without gaining wisdom?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Call out! Is there anyone there to answer you? To which of the holy ones will you turn?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It’s true, the fool is killed by resentment,
and the gullible are put to death by jealousy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I myself have seen a fool putting down roots,
but immediately I pronounced a curse on his home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His children are far from safety.
They are crushed at the city gate without a defender.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His harvest is eaten by the hungry,
    who snatch it away, even from among the thorns,
    and the thirsty swallow his children’s wealth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Disaster does not just spring up from the dust,
nor does trouble sprout from the soil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No, mankind is born for trouble as surely as flames fly upward.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But I want to appeal to God.
I want to present my case to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He does great things that are beyond investigation,
and miracles that are too many to be counted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He provides rain for the earth.
He waters the fields in the countryside.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He raises the lowly to the heights,
and he lifts those who mourn to safety.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He foils the plots of clever schemers,
    so that their hands achieve no success.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He traps the wise in their schemes,
and the plans of the devious come to a swift end.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
By day they encounter darkness,
and at noon they grope around as if it were night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He saves the poor from mouths that cut like a sword
and from the hand of the strong.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He does this so that the helpless will have hope,
and injustice will shut its mouth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Consider this:
How blessed is the man whom God corrects!
Do not reject the discipline of the Almighty!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For though he may inflict wounds, he also bandages them.
Though he may strike, his hands also heal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
From six calamities he will rescue you.
In seven no harm will touch you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In famine he will redeem you from death,
and in battle he will redeem you from the power of the sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will be hidden from the lash of the tongue,
and you will not be afraid of devastation when it comes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will laugh at devastation and hunger.
You will not be afraid of the wild animals of the countryside,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
because there will be a covenant between you and the stones in the field,
and the wild animals will be at peace with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will know that your tent is secure,
and when you inspect your property, you will find nothing missing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will know that your offspring will be many,
and your descendants will be like grass from the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will come to the grave at a ripe old age,
    like a stack of sheaves that is gathered in season.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Consider this:
We have investigated this carefully, and it is true!
Pay close attention and apply it to yourself!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Job responded:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If only my grief could be weighed,
and my devastation placed on the scales with it!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They would certainly weigh more than the sand of the sea!
No wonder my words have been rash.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The arrows of the Almighty stick in me.
My spirit drinks in their poison.
The terrors of God are lined up against me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Does the wild donkey bray when it has green grass?
Does the ox bellow when it is near its fodder?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Is tasteless food eaten without salt?
Is there flavor in the white of an egg?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I absolutely refuse to touch it.
It is no better than sickening food.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If only my request would be granted.
If only God would grant me what I hope for:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
that God would decide to crush me,
    that he would unleash his hand and cut me off.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For then I would still have this comfort:
    Even as I writhe in relentless pain,
    I have not denied the words of the Holy One.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What strength do I have to wait hopefully?
What end awaits me that would make me want to prolong my life?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Is my strength like stone,
or is my flesh bronze?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Certainly I have no power to help myself,
    since the hope that I can recover has been driven far away from me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A despairing person should receive loyalty from his friends,
    even if he forsakes the fear of the Almighty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But my brothers are as undependable as gullies that dry up,
undependable as seasonal streams which overflow
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: when they are darkened by ice and swollen with melting snow,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
but as quickly as they flood, they dry up in the scorching winds.
When it gets hot, they vanish from their channels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Caravans turn aside from their routes.
They go off into the empty wasteland and perish.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The caravans of Tema search for these streams.
The travelers of Sheba hope to find them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
but despite being confident, they are disappointed.
They arrive there only to be frustrated.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Now that is what you are like!
You have seen something dreadful and you panic.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Have I said, “Give me something,
or offer a payment on my behalf from your wealth”?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Have I said, “Save me from the hand of my enemy,
or redeem me from the hand of the ruthless”?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Teach me and I will be silent.
Help me understand what I have done wrong.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How painful honest words are!
But what does your rebuke prove?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do you intend to attack me for mere words
    by treating things said by a despairing man like wind?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
No doubt you would even cast lots for a fatherless child
and barter away your friend!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But now, please look at me.
I would not lie to your face!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Turn to me, and get rid of injustice.
Turn to me. My righteousness is still intact.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Is there any injustice on my tongue?
Wouldn’t my mouth detect it if I were speaking destructive words?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isn’t man’s time on earth like being compelled to serve in the army? Aren’t his days like those of a hired man?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like a slave, he longs for shade,
or like a day laborer, he waits for his pay.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In the same way, I have been allotted months of futility,
and nights of agony have been assigned to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When I lie down, I think, “How long before I get up?”
But the night drags on,
and I am filled with restlessness until dawn.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My flesh is clothed with maggots and caked with dirt.
My skin scabs over and then oozes again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My days pass by more swiftly than the shuttle of a weaver’s loom.
They come to an end without hope.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Remember that my life is just a breath.
My eyes will never again see good fortune.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The eyes that see me now will no longer watch me.
Your eyes will look for me, but I will not be there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As a cloud vanishes and is gone,
so does the one who goes down to the grave.
He does not come back up again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He never again returns to his home,
and his place will no longer know him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
That is why I will not restrain my mouth.
I will speak out in the anguish of my spirit.
I will lament in the bitterness of my soul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Am I the sea or a great creature of the deep
    that you need to put me under guard?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When I say that my bed will comfort me,
and my couch will help me with my lament,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
then you frighten me with dreams
and terrify me with visions,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
so I would prefer to be strangled,
and I prefer death more than my current existence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I reject my life. I do not want to live forever.
Leave me alone, for my days are just a vanishing vapor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What is man that you make so much of him,
that you pay so much attention to him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
that you inspect him every morning
and test him every minute?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why do you never stop watching me?
Why don’t you leave me alone long enough for me to swallow my spit?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If I have sinned, what harm has it done to you,
    you who keep watch on mankind?
Why have you set me up as your target?
How have I become a burden to you?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why do you not forgive my rebellion?
Why do you not take away my guilt?
Soon I will lie down in the dust.
You will search for me, but I will not be there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Bildad the Shuhite responded:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How long will you say such things?
How long will the words of your mouth be like a blustery wind?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Does God pervert justice?
Does the Almighty pervert what is right?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When your children sinned against him,
he handed them over to the consequences of their rebellion.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But if you will eagerly seek God
and plead for compassion from the Almighty,
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Then, though your beginnings were small,
your final days will be very great!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yes, ask the previous generations,
and consider the discoveries of their fathers,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
because we were born only yesterday and know nothing.
Our days on earth are nothing but a shadow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Aren’t our ancestors the ones who should teach you and inform you,
the ones who brought forth words from their hearts?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Does papyrus grow tall where there is no marsh?
Do reeds thrive where there is no water?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
While they are still growing and uncut,
they can wither faster than any other plant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is the way it will be for all those who forget God.
The hope of the godless man perishes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His source of confidence is fragile.
He trusts in something as fragile as a spider’s web.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He leans on his web, but it does not support him.
He grasps it, but it does not hold him up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He is a thriving plant flourishing in the sunshine,
    spreading its shoots over the garden.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It wraps its roots around a heap of rocks.
It finds a home among the stones.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But if it is uprooted from its place,
that place disowns it, saying, “I have never seen you!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yes, the only good thing that comes from this situation is that
    from the dust another plant sprouts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Certainly God does not reject a blameless man
or strengthen the hand of evildoers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He will again fill your mouth with laughter
and your lips with a joyful shout.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your enemies will be clothed with shame,
and the tents of the wicked will be no more.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Job responded:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Of course I know that this is true.
But how can a man be justified before God?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If someone wants to argue with God,
he could not refute one charge out of a thousand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
God has a wise heart and great power,
so who can resist God and come out of it unharmed?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
God removes mountains from their position,
and they don’t even realize it.
He overturns mountains in his anger.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He shakes the earth off its foundation.
He causes its pillars to quake.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He speaks to the sun, and it does not rise,
and he seals up the stars.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He alone stretches out the heavens.
He treads on the crests of the sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He made the Bear, Orion, the Pleiades,
and the constellations in the southern sky.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He does great things that are beyond investigation.
He does miracles that are too many to be counted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Though he passes by me, I do not see him.
He moves past me, but I do not detect him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If he snatches something away, who can make him bring it back?
Who can say to him, “What are you doing?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
God does not hold back his anger.
Even Rahab’s helpers bow down beneath him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How much less, then, will I be able to answer him?
I want to match words with him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
but even if I am in the right, I cannot answer him.
I can only plead to my judge for grace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If I called and he responded to me,
I do not believe that he would listen to my voice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
With a violent storm he would crush me,
and he would inflict many wounds on me for no reason.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He would not allow me to catch my breath.
Instead, he would fill me with bitter experiences.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If it is a question of strength, he definitely is the strong one.
If it is a question of jurisdiction, who can summon him?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Even if I am righteous, my mouth would still condemn me.
If I am blameless, it would pronounce me crooked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Although I am blameless, I cannot evaluate myself.
I reject my own life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Here is why I say, “It makes no difference.”
Blameless or wicked, he brings them all to the same end.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If a whip suddenly kills people,
he makes fun of the despair of the innocent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When a land is handed over to a wicked man,
God blinds the eyes of its judges.
If he is not the one, then who does it?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My days are swifter than a runner.
They fly away without bringing any happiness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They glide by like reed boats,
like an eagle that swoops down on its prey.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If I say, “I will forget my complaint.
I will put on a happy face and smile,”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
even then I dread all my pain,
because I know that you will not acquit me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I have already been declared guilty,
so why should I struggle for nothing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If I wash myself with snow,
if I cleanse my hands with strong soap,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
then you will plunge me into a cesspool,
and my clothes will detest me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For he is not a man as I am,
so that I am able to answer him,
so that we may meet in court.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There is no one to mediate between us,
no one who can lay his hand on both of us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
No one can make him take his rod away from me,
so that the dread of him would not fill me with terror!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If that happened, I would speak up and not be afraid.
But I have no such mediator. I am left on my own.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
With all my heart I am weary of my life,
so I will express my complaint freely.
I will speak from the bitterness of my heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will say this to God: Do not condemn me.
Tell me why you are pressing charges against me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Is it good that you are oppressing me,
that you are rejecting what your hands have made,
at the same time that you favor the plans of the wicked?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do you have eyes made of flesh?
Do you see things the way a man does?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Are your days like a man’s days?
Are your years like the life span of a human?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You do, in fact, investigate guilt,
and you do search carefully for sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Although you know that I am not guilty,
there is no one who can rescue me from your hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your hands shaped me and made me,
but now you swallow me up completely.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Please remember that it was you who shaped me like a clay pot.
Will you now return me to the dust?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Aren’t you the one who poured me out like milk,
who thickened me like a curd of cheese?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You clothed me with skin and flesh.
You wove me together with bones and tendons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You provided me with life and mercy,
and your watchful care has guarded my spirit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You hid these things in your heart,
but I know that this is what you had in mind:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If I sinned and you were watching me,
you would not acquit me of my guilt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If I was wicked, I would be cursed!
But even if I was righteous, I could not lift up my head,
because I am filled with shame and aware of my misery.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If I lift myself up, you hunt me down like a lion.
You turn and display amazing power against me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You produce new witnesses to oppose me,
and you become more irritated with me.
You attack me with reinforcements.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why, then, did you bring me out from the womb?
I wish I had died. Then no eye would have seen me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I wish I had been like someone who never lived.
Then I would have been carried from the womb to the tomb.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Don’t I have only a few days?
Stop! Leave me alone, so that I can be happy for a short time,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
before I walk into the land of darkness
and into the shadow of death, never to return,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
into the land of gloom, as dark as the shadow of death,
into the land of chaos, where even light is darkness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Zophar the Na’amathite spoke up and responded:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Doesn’t this gush of words call for an answer?
Can this man’s bold talk be justified?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Should your empty words reduce men to silence?
Can you be allowed to scoff without anyone putting you in your place?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You say, “What I teach is untainted,
and I am pure in your eyes.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Oh how I wish that God would speak up,
open his lips against you,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and show you the secret of wisdom,
because sound judgment must look at both sides.
Then you would know that God has even forgotten some of your guilt!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Can you explore the essence of God?
Can you find a limit to the perfections of the Almighty?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They are as high as the heavens. What can you do?
They are deeper than hell. What can you know?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His dimensions are greater than the earth
and wider than the sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If God comes and arrests someone and puts him on trial,
who can overrule him?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Certainly he recognizes deceitful men for what they are.
He sees evil, and he recognizes it for what it is.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Before an empty-headed man gets understanding,
a wild donkey colt will be born as a man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But you, if you make your heart steadfast,
and you spread out your hands to him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
if you put away the sin you are holding in your hand,
and you do not allow injustice to dwell in your tents,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
then you will lift up your face and be blameless.
You will be solid and fearless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will certainly forget your trouble.
Your memory of it will be like water that has flowed away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The rest of your life will be brighter than noon.
Darkness will become like morning.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will be confident that there is hope.
When you look around, you will go to bed confidently.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will lie down, and no one will make you tremble.
Many will seek your favor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The eyes of the wicked will fail,
and their place of refuge will disappear.
Their hope will vanish with their dying breath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Job responded:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yes, indeed. You are the people,
and wisdom will die with you!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But I understand things as well as you.
I do not fall short of you.
Who doesn’t know all these things?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But I am a laughingstock to my neighbor—
I, who call on God, and he answers me—
I, a righteous and complete man, am a laughingstock!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Those who are carefree do not worry about disaster.
They think it is reserved for those whose feet are slipping.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The tents of raiders are undisturbed,
and those who provoke God are secure—
those who carry their god in their hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Please ask the animals, and they will teach you.
Ask the birds of the sky, and they will inform you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Complain to the earth, and it will teach you,
and the fish of the sea will tell you about it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Who among all these does not know that the hand of the Lord did this?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The life of every living thing is in his hand,
as well as the breath in all human flesh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Isn’t it true that the ear tests words
and the palate tastes food?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Isn’t it true that wisdom is found among the aged
and understanding among those who have had a long life?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But wisdom and power are with God.
He gives guidance and understanding.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If he tears something down, it cannot be rebuilt.
If he shuts a door on a man, it cannot be opened.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Look! He holds back the waters, and the land dries up.
He turns them loose, and the earth is overwhelmed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He has strength and sound judgment.
The deceiver and the deceived both belong to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He causes royal advisors to be led away naked.
He makes fools of judges.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He takes away the ruling power of kings,
and he wraps a loincloth around their waist.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He causes priests to be led away naked,
and he brings the pillars of society down to ruin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He closes the lips of trusted advisors,
and he takes away good judgment from elders.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He pours contempt on nobles.
He loosens the belt of the strong.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He uncovers deep mysteries that were hidden in darkness.
He brings the shadow of death into the light.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He raises nations to power, and then he destroys them.
He enlarges nations, and then he leads them away captive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He deprives the heads of the peoples of the earth of their reason.
He makes them wander in a wild land where there are no roads.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They grope around in darkness, where there is no light.
He causes them to wander aimlessly like drunks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My eyes have certainly seen all this.
My ears have heard it and understood it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Whatever you know, I know every bit as well.
I do not fall short of you in any way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But I want to speak to the Almighty.
I am eager to argue my case with God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All you do is plaster over problems with lies.
Such useless healers, all of you!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I wish you would shut up completely.
For you, that would be wisdom!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But now, listen to my rebuttal.
Pay attention to the arguments from my lips.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Will you misrepresent God?
Will you speak deceitfully about him?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Will you show favoritism on behalf of God
and argue his case for him?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Will it turn out well when he cross-examines you?
Can you fool God as you can fool a man?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will certainly rule against you if you hide your favoritism.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Won’t God’s majesty frighten you?
Won’t the dread he inspires overwhelm you?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your axioms are proverbs made of ashes.
Your strong points are made of clay.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Silence! Let me speak.
I intend to speak up, no matter what happens.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why do I bite my flesh with my teeth?
Why do I take my life in my hands?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Even if he slays me, I will wait for him with hope.
No matter what, I will defend my ways to his face.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Even this may turn out for my salvation,
for no godless person would dare to face him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Listen carefully to my words!
Give my testimony a hearing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Please, listen. I have laid out my case.
I know that I am innocent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who can make a case against me?
If anyone can, I will be quiet and die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Just do two things for me, God.
If you do, I will not hide from your face.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Take your hands off me,
and do not terrify me with your grandeur.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Summon me, and I will answer.
Or, I will speak, and you can respond to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How much guilt and how many sins do I have?
Reveal my rebellion and my sin to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why do you hide your face?
Why do you treat me like your enemy?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Will you toss me around like a wind-blown leaf?
Will you chase me away like dry chaff?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You write bitter accusations against me,
and you hold me accountable for the guilt of my youth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You lock my feet in stocks
and station guards along all my paths.
You put your brand on the soles of my feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So a man rots away like a garment eaten by moths.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Man born of woman has a few short days,
and they are full of anxiety.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He blossoms like a flower, but soon withers.
He recedes like a shadow and does not remain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You keep your eye on such a man.
You bring me into judgment in your presence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who can produce something pure from something that is impure?
No one.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Certainly his days are determined.
The number of his months has been set by you.
A limit is set, which he cannot exceed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Turn your gaze away from him, and let him be,
until he finishes his day’s work as a hired man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There is still hope for a tree if it is cut down.
It may grow up again and produce new shoots.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Though its roots lie dormant in the earth,
and its stump is dying in the dust,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
with just a whiff of water, it shoots up again.
As a growing plant, it again sends out branches.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But if a man dies, he shrivels away.
When a person breathes his last, where is he?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Waters evaporate from the sea.
A river dries up and becomes dust.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In the same way, a man lies down and does not rise again.
Until the heavens pass away, he does not awaken,
and he is not aroused from his sleep.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Oh how I wish you would hide me in the grave,
that you would conceal me until your wrath has passed by,
that you would set an appointed time for me,
and then you would remember me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If a man dies, will he live again?
Through all the days of my warfare,
I will wait, until change comes about for me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will call, and I myself will answer.
Then you will long for the work of your hands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Now you count my steps,
but then you will no longer keep track of my sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My rebellious deeds will be sealed up in a bag,
and you will plaster over my guilt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But as a mountain crumbles and falls,
and as a rock is moved from its place,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
as water wears away stones,
and floodwaters wash away soil from the land,
so you destroy a man’s hope.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You overpower him once and for all, and he passes away.
You change his appearance and send him away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His sons are honored, but he is not aware of it.
They are brought low, but he does not realize it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He feels the pain only of his own flesh,
and in his soul grieves only for himself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Eliphaz the Temanite responded:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Does a wise man answer with windy bluster?
Does he fill his belly with the hot east wind?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Does he support his arguments with useless talk,
with words that provide no benefit?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But you even tear down reverence.
You hinder thoughtful reflection in the presence of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your guilt instructs your mouth.
You choose deceptive language.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your own mouth condemns you, not mine.
Your own lips testify against you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Were you the first man to be born?
Were you brought forth before the hills?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do you listen in on the council meetings of God?
Do you lay claim to all wisdom for yourself?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What do you know that we do not know as well?
What do you understand that we do not?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The gray-haired and the aged are on our side,
men older than your father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Are the consolations of God too small for you?
Do you think nothing of the gentle words spoken to you?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why does your heart carry you away?
Why do your eyes flash with such anger?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why do you turn your spirit against God?
Why do you allow such words to pour out of your mouth?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What is man, that he could be pure,
or one born of woman, that he could be declared righteous?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If God does not trust in his holy ones,
and even the heavens are not pure in his eyes,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
how much less man who is repulsive and corrupt,
who drinks down injustice like water!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Let me instruct you! Listen to me!
This is what I have seen. Let me tell you about it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what wise men have declared,
wise men who hid nothing of what they had received from their fathers,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
to whom alone the land was given,
        at a time when no foreigners were present in their midst.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Through all his days, a wicked man writhes in pain,
throughout the whole number of years stored up for a tyrant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Terrifying sounds echo in his ears.
In peacetime the plunderer arrives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The wicked man does not believe that he will return from darkness.
He is sentenced to the sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He wanders around looking for food and asks, “Where is it?”
He knows that a day of darkness is at hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Pressure and distress terrify him.
They overpower him, like a king ready to attack,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
because he has stretched out his hand against God,
and he has been arrogant toward the Almighty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He charges at him defiantly with a thick shield.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Though now his face is covered with its fat,
and his hips bulge with lard,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
he will live in ruined cities,
in abandoned houses, reduced to rubble.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He will no longer be rich.
His wealth will not last.
His possessions will no longer cover the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He will not escape from darkness.
Flames will dry up his shoots.
With a breath from God’s mouth, he will depart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He should not trust in useless things.
He should not fool himself.
His only reward will be useless things.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Before his time, he will be paid in full.
His palm branches will not be green.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His grapes will be shaken from the vine before they are ripe.
He will be like an olive tree that loses its blossoms.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In the end, the community of the godless produces nothing,
and fire consumes the tents of those who take bribes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They conceive trouble and give birth to disaster.
Their womb produces treachery.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Job responded:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I have heard many things just like these.
You are miserable comforters, all of you!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Is there any end to your windy words?
What provokes you to respond like this?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I also could speak just like you,
if your lives were in the same condition that my life is.
I could weave fancy words against you
and shake my head at you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But instead, I would build you up with the words from my mouth,
and comforting words from my lips would ease your pain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Now if I speak up, it does not lessen my pain,
and if I hold back, how much of my pain goes away?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Surely, he has worn me out!
You have devastated everyone close to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You have made me shrivel up,
and this testifies against me.
My emaciated body stands up
and is a witness against me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His anger has torn me.
He has been hostile to me.
He has gnashed his teeth at me.
My opponent glares at me with piercing eyes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
People have opened their mouths wide against me.
They have slapped my face with contempt.
They have ganged up on me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
God hands me over to evil people.
He throws me into the hands of the wicked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When I was at ease, he shattered me.
He seized me by the neck and has ripped me to pieces.
He has set me up as his target.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His archers surround me.
He pierces my kidneys and has no pity.
He pours out my bile on the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He breaks down my walls in many places.
He runs against me like a warrior.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I have stitched sackcloth to my skin.
My horn is stuck in the dust.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My face is red from my weeping.
There are dark circles under my eyes,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
even though there is no violence in my hands,
and my prayer is pure.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
O earth, do not cover my blood.
Let my cry never find a place to rest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Even now, my witness is in heaven.
My advocate is on high.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My intercessor is my friend.
My eyes never stop weeping to God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My intercessor pleads with God for a man,
as another human pleads for his friend.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A few more years will come.
Then I will go the way of no return.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My spirit is broken.
My days are snuffed out.
The tomb is waiting for me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Surely mockery closes in on me.
My eyes must live with my enemies’ bitter contempt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Please pay for me the deposit that you require from me.
Indeed, who else could guarantee this payment for me?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You have hidden understanding from their hearts.
Therefore, you will not let them win.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If someone denounces friends for a payoff,
his children’s eyes will fail.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He has made me a laughingstock among the people.
They spit in my face.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My vision is blurry from grief.
I am just a shadow of myself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The upright are appalled at this,
and the innocent are aroused against the godless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In spite of it all, the righteous hold tight to their ways,
and everyone with clean hands grows stronger.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All right then—all of you, please come and try again,
but I will not find a wise man among you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My days have passed.
All the things I planned to do are ripped apart,
including the deepest desires of my heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They turn night into day.
In the face of darkness, they claim light is near.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If I wait hopefully for the grave to become my house,
if I spread out my bed in the darkness,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
if I cry out to the pit, “You are my father,”
and to the worm, “My mother” or “My sister,”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
where then is my hope?
Who can find any hope for me?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Will it go down with me to the barred gates of the grave?
Will we rest in the dust together?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Bildad the Shuhite responded:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How much longer are all of you going to keep hunting for words?
Come to your senses! Then we can talk.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why are we considered to be like cattle?
Why are we regarded as unreasoning animals in your eyes?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You, who tear yourself to pieces with your anger,
do you expect the earth to be made desolate for your sake?
Should rocks be moved from their place for you?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The light of the wicked has been extinguished,
and not a spark of his flame still shines.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In his tent, light becomes darkness
when the lamp beside him goes out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His powerful strides are tangled up,
and his own plans bring him down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yes, his feet are caught in a net,
and he stumbles into its webbing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A trap snaps at his heel,
and a snare catches him firmly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A noose lies hidden on the ground for him.
A trap is set on his path.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Terrors frighten him on every side.
They harass him at every step.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His strength is eaten away by hunger,
and disaster is waiting for him to stumble.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It eats away pieces of his skin.
Death’s firstborn child eats away pieces of him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He is torn away from the safety of his tent.
He is marched off to the king of terrors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Nothing that belonged to him remains in his tent.
Sulfur is scattered over his dwelling.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His roots dry up below,
and his branches wither above.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All memory of him perishes from the earth.
No one on the street remembers his name.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He is pushed away from the light into the darkness.
He is chased out of the world.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He has no posterity or descendants among his people.
He leaves no survivor in his place, where he lived as an alien.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
People in the west shudder at his fate.
People in the east are overcome with horror.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Certainly this is the dwelling place for an evil man.
This is the place for one who does not acknowledge God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Job responded:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How long will you torment my soul?
How long will you crush me with words?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Ten times now you have insulted me,
but you are not ashamed that you are treating me so badly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But even if I actually were in the wrong,
my error would remain my own concern.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
To be sure, when you lord it over me,
and you hurl my disgrace against me,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
you should know that God has denied me justice,
and he has trapped me in his net.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Listen to me!
I cry out, “Injustice,” but I get no answer.
I call for help, but there is no justice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He has blocked my way, so I cannot get by.
He has brought darkness on my paths.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He has stripped me of my honor,
and he has taken the crown off my head.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He tears me down on every side, until I am gone.
He uproots my hope like a tree.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His anger burns against me,
and he regards me as his enemy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Together his troops advance against me.
They build a siege ramp against me.
They camp all around my tent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He has distanced my brothers far from me,
and those who know me treat me like a stranger.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My relatives stay away.
Even my close friends have forgotten me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Even my houseguests and my female servants treat me like a stranger.
They look upon me as a foreigner.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I summon my servant, but he does not answer,
even though I beg him to be gracious to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My breath keeps my wife away from me,
and I am repulsive to my mother’s children.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Even young boys reject me.
When I get up, they speak against me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My closest confidants shun me,
and those I love have turned against me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I am nothing but skin and bones.
I have escaped with the skin of my teeth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Have mercy on me.
Have mercy on me, you friends of mine,
because the hand of God has struck me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why do you pursue me the way God does?
Will you never get enough of my flesh?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Oh how I wish that my words were written down.
Oh how I wish that they were inscribed in bronze,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
that they would be engraved in rock forever
with an iron tool and letters filled with lead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As for me, I know that my Redeemer lives,
and that at the end of time he will stand over the dust.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then, even after my skin has been destroyed,
nevertheless, in my own flesh I will see God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I myself will see him.
My own eyes will see him, and not as a stranger.
My emotions are in turmoil within me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If you say, “What can we do to pursue him?”
and “He is the root of his own problems,”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
then you should fear the edge of the sword for yourselves!
For wrath brings the punishment of the sword,
so that you will know that there is judgment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Zophar the Na’amathite responded:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is why my troubled thoughts make me respond again,
and why my thoughts are racing through my mind:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I heard a rebuke that insults me,
so my spirit prompts me to respond with understanding.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
the triumphant cry of the wicked has been short-lived,
and the joy of the godless lasts only a moment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Although his arrogance reaches up to the skies,
and his head touches the clouds,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
he will perish forever like his own filth.
Those who saw him will say, “Where is he?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Like a dream, he flies away, and he cannot be found.
Like a vision during the night, he flutters away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
An eye catches sight of him, but it does not see him again.
His place will no longer look at him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His children must make restitution to the poor.
His hands must give back his wealth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His bones were once filled with youthful vigor,
but that vigor will lie down with him in the dust.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If evil tastes sweet in his mouth,
and he tucks it under his tongue,
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text: his food will turn into cobra venom in his stomach.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He swallowed wealth, but he vomits it up.
God makes him expel it from his belly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He sucks the poison of cobras.
The fangs of a viper kill him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He will not see the streams,
the rivers that flow with honey and cream.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Without digesting it, he gives up the produce for which he labored.
He does not enjoy the wealth for which he traded,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
because he has crushed and abandoned the poor,
and he has stolen a house he did not build.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His stomach is never filled.
He cannot satisfy his desires,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
because now there is nothing left for him to eat,
so his prosperity will not endure.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Even when he has plenty,
distress catches up with him,
and misery grabs hold of him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
While he is filling his belly,
God will send burning anger upon him,
and it will rain down on his body.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He flees from iron weapons,
but he is pierced by a bronze arrow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He pulls the arrow out of his back,
and the shiny point comes out of his liver.
Terrors come over him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Complete darkness is lying in wait for his hidden treasures.
A fire that needs no fanning will consume him.
It will destroy anything that survives in his tent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The heavens will uncover his guilt,
and the earth will rise up against him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A flood will carry away his house,
sweeping away his possessions on the day of God’s wrath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is God’s sentence on the evil man.
This is his heritage decreed by God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Job responded:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Listen carefully to my words—
that is the kind of encouragement you should give me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Put up with me while I speak.
Then, after I have spoken, you may resume your mocking.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Is my complaint against a man?
Why shouldn’t I be impatient?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Look at me and be shocked,
and then put your hand over your mouth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When I remember all this, I am terrified,
and horror makes my flesh tremble.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why do the wicked keep living,
reach old age,
and even become stronger?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Their descendants are firmly established in their presence,
and they live long enough to see their offspring.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Their houses are safe from fear,
and God’s rod does not strike them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The wicked man’s bulls breed without failing.
His cows deliver calves without miscarrying.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Their toddlers frolic like flocks,
and their children dance around.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They sing to the accompaniment of hand drums and lyres.
They celebrate to the sound of a flute.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They finish out their days in prosperity.
Then they go down to the grave in a moment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They say to God, “Keep away from us.
We know your ways, but we find no pleasure in them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Who is the Almighty, that we should serve him,
and what benefit do we gain from pleading with him?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But I know that their prosperity is not in their own hands,
so I have distanced myself from the way of life of the wicked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How often is the lamp of the wicked extinguished?
How often does the disaster they deserve come upon them?
How often does God in his anger dole out their fair share of pain?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How often are they like straw blown by the wind,
like chaff that a windstorm whisks away?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
People say, “God stores up a man’s punishment for his children,”
but he should repay the man himself so that he experiences it!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Let his own eyes see his condemnation.
Let him drink from the rage of the Almighty,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
for what does he care about his household after his death,
when his allotment of months has run out?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Can anyone teach God knowledge,
since he judges even the most exalted ones?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
One person dies with vigor in his bones,
completely secure and at ease.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His body is filled out with fat,
and his bones are rich with marrow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Another person dies with his soul filled with bitterness,
without ever tasting anything good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Both of them lie down together in the dust,
and worms cover them both.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Oh, I know your thoughts
and your schemes to harm me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For you say, “Where is the nobleman’s house,
and where is the tent, which was the dwelling of the wicked?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why don’t you question those who travel the roads?
Why don’t you acknowledge the lessons they learned?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They say that the wicked man is spared from the day of disaster,
and that he escapes the day of raging fury.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who denounces him to his face for the way he has lived?
Who repays him for what he has done?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When he is carried to the tombs,
when a vigil is kept at his burial mound,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
the clods of dirt from the streambed are sweet to him.
Everyone follows his funeral procession.
A crowd of people marches ahead of it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So how can you comfort me with your useless words?
There is nothing left from your answers but fraud!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Eliphaz the Temanite responded:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Can a man benefit God?
Can even a wise man be of any use to him?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Should the Almighty be delighted if you are righteous?
Does he gain any advantage if your ways are blameless?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Is it because of your reverence that he rebukes you
and comes against you in judgment?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Isn’t your wickedness great?
Isn’t your guilt endless?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You have seized collateral from your brothers without cause,
and you have stripped off clothing from the naked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You have not given water to the weary,
and you have withheld bread from the hungry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The earth belongs to a forceful man,
and a well-respected man dwells in it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You send widows away empty-handed.
You crush the arms of the fatherless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
That is why snares are all around you,
and sudden fear overwhelms you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
That is why you cannot see in the darkness,
and floodwaters cover you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Is not God in the heights of heaven?
Look at the highest stars, so high above!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But you say, “What does God know?
Can he judge through the thick darkness?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Dark clouds are a veil around him,
so he does not see us
as he walks back and forth in heaven’s dome.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Are you the guardian of the ancient way,
    the one traveled by wicked men?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They were snatched away before their time.
Their foundation was washed away by a river.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They said to God, “Keep away from us,”
and “What can the Almighty do to us?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
even though he had filled their houses with good.
That is why the way of life of the wicked is far from me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The righteous see this and are glad.
The innocent mock them, saying,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Surely our adversaries have been erased!
Fire has eaten up their abundance.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Be reconciled with God.
Be at peace with him.
Then good will come to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Accept teaching from his mouth,
and set his words in your heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If you turn to the Almighty, you will be built up.
If you want to put injustice far from your tent,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
throw your purest gold into the dust
and your gold from Ophir upon the rocks in the ravines.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the Almighty will be your purest gold
and your most precious silver.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then you will find pleasure in the Almighty,
and you will lift up your face to God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will pray to God, and he will hear you,
and you will fulfill your vows.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will decide on a matter, and it will be done for you,
and light will shine on your ways.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When people are brought low,
and you say, “Lift them up,”
God will save the downcast.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He will deliver even the person who is not innocent,
who will escape by the purity of your hands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Job responded:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Even today my complaint is bitter.
His hand weighs heavily on me despite my groaning.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I wish I knew where I could find him,
so that I could come to his place for judgment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then I would lay out my case before him,
and I would fill my mouth with arguments.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I would know what words he would use to respond to me,
and I would consider what he would say to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Would he use his great power to press charges against me?
No, he will certainly give me a hearing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There, an upright man could argue with him,
and I would be delivered from my judge forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But if I walk to the east, he is not there.
If I go back to the west, I find no sign of him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When he is at work in the north, I do not detect him.
When he turns to the south, I do not see him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But I am sure he knows the way I take.
When he has tested me, I will come out like gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My feet have followed his footsteps closely.
I have kept to his way, and I have not turned aside.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I have not departed from the command from his lips.
I have treasured the sayings from his mouth in my heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He stands alone.
Who can make him change?
Whatever his soul desires, he will do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He carries out his decrees against me,
and he has so many of them!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
That is why I am in a panic in his presence.
When I think about this, I dread him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
God has made me lose heart.
The Almighty has terrified me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Nevertheless, I am not silenced by the darkness,
by the dark cloud that covers my face.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why are appointments never scheduled by the Almighty?
Why do those who know him never see such days?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
People move boundary stones.
They steal a flock and take it to pasture.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They drive away donkeys that belong to the fatherless.
They seize the widow’s ox as collateral.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They shove the poor out of the way.
The oppressed people of the land hide together.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They go out to their labor, like wild donkeys in the wilderness,
    looking for food.
The wasteland is their only source of food for themselves
    and their children.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They gather their straw in the open countryside.
They glean leftovers in the vineyard of the wicked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They spend the night naked, without clothing.
They have no covering from the cold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They are soaked by heavy rain from the mountains.
They cling to a cliff for shelter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The wicked tear away a fatherless child from its mother’s breast.
They take a poor mother’s nursing baby as collateral.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The poor walk around naked, without clothing.
They pick up sheaves but are still hungry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They press olive oil among the terraces of olive trees.
They tread winepresses, but they remain thirsty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The dying people of the city groan,
and wounded souls cry out for help,
but God does not bring charges against anyone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There are people who rebel against the light.
They do not acknowledge its ways or dwell in its paths.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
At the end of the daylight a murderer arises,
and he kills the poor and needy.
At night he acts as a thief.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The eye of an adulterer keeps watch for twilight.
He says, “No eye can get a good look at me.”
He wears a mask over his face.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In the dark of night he digs into houses.
By day such people hide inside.
They keep away from the light.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For all of them, morning is their darkness.
They are familiar with the sudden terror of darkness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They float by like foam on the surface of the water.
Their portion of the land is cursed,
so no one turns onto the road to their vineyards.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As drought and heat snatch away the water from the snow,
the grave snatches away a sinner.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The womb forgets him.
A worm finds him sweet.
He will no longer be remembered.
Wickedness is broken like a tree.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He feeds on the childless woman,
and he does nothing good for the widow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But God drags away the mighty by his strength.
He rises up, so the wicked have no confidence in their lives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
God lets them be secure, and they prop themselves up,
but God’s eyes are on their ways.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They are high and mighty for a little while,
but then they are gone.
They are brought low like all the rest.
They are gathered together, like ears of grain that have been cut off.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So then, who can make me out to be a liar?
Who can reduce my words to nothing?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Bildad the Shuhite responded:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The power to rule and to inspire fear belongs to him.
He makes peace on high.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Can anyone count his troops?
Is there anyone on whom his light does not rise?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How then can a man be righteous with God?
How can one born of a woman be pure?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If even the moon does not shine brightly for him,
and if the stars are not pure in his eyes,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
how much less a man, who is a maggot,
and a son of man, who is a worm?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Job responded:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How marvelously you have helped the helpless!
How wonderfully you have saved the arm that has no strength!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What great advice you have given to the one who lacks wisdom!
What great insight you have revealed!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who helped you proclaim these words?
Whose breath came out of your mouth?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The spirits of the dead writhe in pain underneath the waters,
along with all those who dwell there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Hell is naked before God,
and there is nowhere to hide in the place of destruction.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He stretches out the northern sky across the emptiness.
He suspends the earth on nothing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He encloses water in his clouds,
but the clouds are not broken apart by its weight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He dims the face of the full moon by veiling it with his clouds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He drew a circle around the surface of the waters.
It marks the boundary of light and darkness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The pillars of the heavens shake.
They are stunned by his rebuke.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
By his power he calmed the sea.
By his understanding he smashed Rahab.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
By his breath the skies became beautiful.
His hand pierced the fleeing serpent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But all these are just the fringe of his ways!
How faint a whisper we hear of him!
Who understands his power, which is displayed in the thunder?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After a pause, Job began to present this discourse:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As God lives, he has deprived me of justice.
