The Almighty has made my life bitter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yes, as long as the breath of life is still in me,
as long as the breath from God is still in my nostrils,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
my lips will not speak wickedness,
and my tongue will not murmur deception.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
May I be cursed if I ever admit you are right.
Until I die, I will never deny my integrity.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I have held tight to my righteousness,
and I will not let it go.
My conscience will not accuse me as long as I live.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
May my enemy be like the wicked.
May the one who rises up against me be like the unjust.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For what hope is there for a godless person when God cuts him off,
when God takes away his life?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Will God hear his cry when distress comes upon him?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Will he take delight in the Almighty?
Will he call upon God at all times?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will teach you about the hand of God.
I will not hide what the Almighty is doing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Listen, all of you have observed this.
So why do you continue to spew forth such worthless vapor?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is the allotment a wicked man receives from God,
the inheritance that tyrants receive from the Almighty:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Although his children are many, they are sent to the sword.
His offspring will not be satisfied with bread.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Those who survive will be buried by a plague.
They will be buried, and their widows will not weep.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Though the wicked man piles up silver like dust,
and he accumulates clothing like mounds of clay,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
the righteous will wear what he accumulated,
and the innocent will divide his silver.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He has built a house, but it will be like a moth’s cocoon,
like a shack that a watchman has put up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He goes to bed as a rich man,
but his wealth does not remain.
He opens his eyes, and it is all gone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Terrors sweep over him like floodwaters.
At night, a strong wind carries him away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The east wind lifts him up, and off he goes.
It blows him away from his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It hurls itself at him, and it does not spare him.
He flees from its power as fast as he can.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It mockingly claps its hands at him
and drives him from his place with hissing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yes, there is a mine for silver
and a place where gold is refined.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Iron is taken from the ground,
and copper is smelted out of stone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A miner puts an end to darkness by exploring its farthest limits.
He looks for ore in the gloom and in the deep darkness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He breaks open a mineshaft far from where settlers live,
in places no one has walked before.
Far away from other people, he dangles and sways.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The earth’s surface produces food,
but its depths are overturned as if by fire,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
in places where the stones are sapphires
and the dust is gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
No scavenging bird knows the way there,
and the eyes of vultures have not seen it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king of beasts has not set foot on it.
The lion has not prowled there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The miner’s hand attacks the hard rock.
He overturns the roots of the mountain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He cuts tunnels into the rocks,
and his eyes see every treasure.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He dams up even the trickling water from the rivers,
and he brings light to the earth’s hidden places.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But wisdom—where can it be found?
Where is the place for understanding?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Mankind does not know where it is kept.
It is not found in the land of the living.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The deep ocean says, “It is not in me!”
The sea says, “It is not with me!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It cannot be purchased with the best gold,
and silver cannot be weighed out as its price.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It cannot be bought with the gold of Ophir
or with precious onyx or sapphires.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Gold and crystal cannot be compared to it.
The finest gold jewelry cannot be substituted for it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Coral and quartz are not worth mentioning,
and the value of wisdom is greater than a bag of rubies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The chrysolite of Cush cannot be compared with it.
It cannot be purchased even with pure gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But what about wisdom—where does it come from?
And where is the place to find understanding?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It is hidden from the eyes of all the living.
It is concealed from the birds of the sky.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Destruction and Death say,
“With our ears we have heard only a rumor about it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
God understands the way to it,
and he alone knows its place,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
because he watches the ends of the earth,
and he sees everything under the heavens.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He determines the weight of the wind,
and he measures out the waters by volume.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He made a decree for the rain
and established a path for the roaring thunderstorm.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He saw wisdom and appraised its value.
He established it and also explored it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then he said to mankind:
Listen carefully. The fear of the Lord—that is wisdom,
and to turn away from evil is understanding.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Job resumed his discourse. He said:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Oh how I wish I could be as I used to be
    in the months gone by,
    in the days when God used to watch over me,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
when his lamp was shining over my head,
and I walked through darkness toward his light,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
when I was in my prime,
and the friendly guidance of God was over my tent,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
when the Almighty was still with me,
and my children still surrounded me,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
when my footsteps were washed in cream,
and a rock poured out streams of oil for me,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
when I went out to the gatehouse of the city,
and I took my customary seat in the public square.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The young men saw me and stepped aside.
The elders rose and remained standing in my presence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The officials held back their words.
They placed their hands over their mouths.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The voices of the nobles fell silent.
Their tongues stuck to the roof of their mouths.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Every ear that heard what I said called me blessed.
Every eye that saw what I did testified on my behalf.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Because I saved the poor when they cried for help
and the fatherless when they had no helper,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
the blessing of the dying rested upon me,
and I made the heart of the widow happy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I dressed myself with righteousness,
and it clothed me.
My justice clothed me like a robe and a turban.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I was eyes for the blind and feet for the lame.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I was a father for the needy.
I investigated their cases for people I did not know.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I shattered the fangs of the wicked,
and I snatched their prey from their teeth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So I thought: “I will pass away in my own nest,
after multiplying my days like grains of sand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My roots will be soaked with water,
and dew will settle on my branches at night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My honor will always be fresh for me,
and my bow in my hand will never wear out.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
People listened to me eagerly.
They kept silent, waiting for my advice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
After I spoke, they did not keep speaking.
My words fell on them gently.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They waited for me the way people wait for rain.
They opened their mouths the way people wait for spring showers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When I laughed with them, they did not believe it.
In the light from my face, they were never downcast.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I chose the way for them,
and I was seated as their head,
like a king among the troops,
like one who comforts mourners.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But those far younger than I am now laugh at me—
men whose fathers I would not have allowed
    to serve with my sheepdogs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The strength of their hands was useless to me.
Their vigor had failed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Emaciated from famine and hunger,
they gnawed desert plants in the desolate wasteland.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They picked marsh plants among the brush,
and their food was the roots of broom bushes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They were driven out of the community.
People shouted at them like thieves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They lived in dry streambeds,
in holes among the dust and the rocks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They brayed between shrubs,
and they huddled under thorn bushes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Sons of fools and nameless nobodies,
they were driven out of the land with whips.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But now I am the target of their mocking songs,
and my name has become proverbial as a term of scorn.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They despise me and keep their distance.
They do not hesitate to spit in my face.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
God has unhooked my bowstring,
and he has afflicted me,
so they throw off all restraint in my presence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
At my right hand this rabble rises up like a mob.
They trip my feet.
They besiege me with their plans to destroy me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They cut off my path to escape.
They try to benefit from my destruction.
They need no one to help them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They pour through the breach in my wall.
They roll in through the ruins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Terrors are unleashed against me.
My prestige is blown away by the wind.
My security has passed by like a cloud.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Now my soul is being poured out within me.
Days of suffering have seized me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Night pierces my bones with pain.
The pain gnawing at me never stops.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
God tugs violently at my clothing.
He chokes me like the collar of my robe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He has thrown me into the mud,
and I have become like dust and ashes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I cry to you for help, but you do not answer me.
Whenever I stand up, you pay no attention to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You have become cruel to me.
With a strong hand you assault me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You lift me up with the wind, and it carries me away.
You scatter me in the raging storm.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yes, I know that you are bringing me down to death,
to the home where all the living meet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Will he really stretch out his hand against a pile of ruins,
when the ruined man screams for help?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Didn’t I weep for those who live through hard days?
Didn’t my soul grieve for the needy?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But when I waited for good, evil came.
When I hoped for light, darkness came.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My emotions are boiling over.
They are never quiet.
Days of suffering confront me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I walk around darkened, but not by the sun.
I stand in the assembly and cry for help.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I have become a brother to jackals,
a companion for screeching ostriches.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My skin turns black and falls off,
and my bones burn with fever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My lyre plays only sad songs.
My flute accompanies only the sound of weeping.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I have made a covenant with my eyes.
How then could I stare at a virgin with desire?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If I did, what reward would I receive from God above?
What inheritance from the Almighty on high?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Is not ruin the reward for the wicked,
and misfortune the reward for evildoers?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But doesn’t God see my ways?
Doesn’t he count my every step?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Have I walked with deceit and lies?
Has my foot hurried to pursue fraud?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If God weighs me on an honest scale,
he will know my integrity.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
then let someone else eat what I have sown.
Let my crops be uprooted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If my heart has been enticed by a woman,
if I have lurked at my neighbor’s doorway,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
let my wife grind for another,
and let other men crouch down over her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
For that would have been shameful behavior,
a guilty deed worthy of judgment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There is a fire that consumes all the way to hell,
that would completely burn up all my harvest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If I have denied justice to my male servants
or to my female servants in their disputes with me,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
then what would I do when God arises,
when he comes to call me to account?
How could I respond to him?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Didn’t he who made me in the womb also make my servant?
Didn’t the same God fashion us both in the womb?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If I have withheld from the poor what they desired,
if I have darkened the eyes of the widow,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
if I have eaten my food all by myself
and have not shared it with the fatherless—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
no, from the time of my youth, the fatherless child grew up with me,
and I was like a father to him.
From the womb of my mother I guided the widow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If I saw anyone perishing from lack of clothing,
if the needy had nothing to wear,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
his very body blessed me,
    as he was warmed by the wool from my sheep.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If I raised my hand against the fatherless child,
    because I had influence in the court at the city gate,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
then let my shoulder be knocked out of its socket,
and let my upper arm be broken.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Now doom from God terrifies me,
and I cannot endure his majesty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If I placed my confidence in gold,
and if I said to pure gold, “You are my security,”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
if I rejoiced because I was so rich
and because my hand had obtained so much,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: if I saw the shining sun and the moon moving in its splendor,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
if my heart was gullible enough to worship them in secret,
and I kissed my hand to honor them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
that would have made me guilty and deserving of judgment,
for I would have denied God above.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If I rejoiced at the misfortune of someone who hates me,
or I was thrilled because trouble caught up with him—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but no, I have not savored sin by asking for a curse on his life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Did the men in my tent ever have to say
    that there was someone who had not been filled with meat from Job?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
No stranger ever had to spend the night outside.
I have opened my door to the traveler.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If I had covered up my sin like Adam,
and I had hidden my guilt in my heart,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
because I was frightened of the crowd,
and the contempt of the clans filled me with terror,
so that I was silent and I did not go out of a door—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Oh how I wish I had someone to listen to me!
Look, here is my seal on my testimony.
Let the Almighty answer me!
Let me see the written indictment from my accuser.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I would lift it up on my shoulder.
I would place it on my head as a crown.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I would account to him for every single step.
I would approach him like the chief of a tribe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If my soil cries out against me,
and its furrows weep because of me,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
if I have consumed its wealth without paying for it,
if I have caused the death of its owners,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
then let a thorn bush grow up instead of wheat,
and stinkweeds instead of barley.
The words of Job are concluded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These three men gave up trying to answer Job, because he was righteous in his own eyes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Elihu son of Barakel, the Buzite from the clan of Ram, burned with anger. His anger burned against Job because Job had justified himself rather than God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His anger also burned against his three companions, because they had no answer for Job, but they nevertheless had condemned him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Up to this point, Elihu had held back, and he had not spoken to Job, because the others were older and more experienced than he was.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Elihu saw that the three men had no ready answer, his anger burned.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So Elihu son of Barakel, the Buzite, responded. He said:
I am young and inexperienced, and you are aged.
That is why I held back,
and I was afraid to tell you what I know.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I thought that experience should speak.
Many years should give a man wisdom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
However, it is the spirit in a man
and the breath of the Almighty that give a man understanding.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It is not just the important men who are wise.
The elderly are not the only ones who know how to judge cases.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
That is why I now say, “Listen to me.”
I will declare what I know—yes, I will.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Notice that I waited for you to finish your words.
I have listened carefully to your conclusions.
The whole time you were searching for the right words,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I paid attention to you.
But look, not one of you showed Job that he was wrong
or came up with an answer for Job.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So do not say, “We have found wisdom,
but it is God, not a man, who will have to refute him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Job has not drawn up his speeches against me,
so I will not respond to him with arguments like yours.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Those three are shattered. They no longer respond.
They have run out of words.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I have waited patiently,
but since they no longer speak,
and they just stand there and do not answer anymore,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will now respond with my contribution.
I will now declare what I know,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
for I am full of words.
A wind in my belly is building up pressure.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My belly is like unvented wine.
I am like a new wineskin ready to burst.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I intend to speak, so that I can find relief for myself.
Let me open my lips and answer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will certainly not show favoritism to any man.
I will not address any man with flattering titles,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
because I do not know how to pass out flattering titles.
If I did so, my Maker would quickly carry me away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But now, Job, listen to my speech.
Pay close attention to all my words.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Listen, because I have opened my mouth.
See how my tongue shapes words in my mouth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My speech will reveal my upright heart.
My lips express my knowledge plainly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The spirit of God made me.
The breath of the Almighty gave me life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Refute me if you are able.
Lay out your case before me! Take your stand!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Look, my mouth belongs to God, just as your mouth does.
Like you I was snipped off from a lump of clay.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Look, you should not be terrified by how awesome I am.
Pressure from me should not intimidate you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
However, you said this in my hearing,
and I did hear the sound of these words:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“I am pure, without any sinful rebellion.
I am clean. I have no guilt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But look how God finds pretexts to oppose me.
He treats me like his enemy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He has put my feet in stocks.
He patrols all my paths.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Job, listen to this!
You are not right.
I must refute you!
Certainly, God is greater than a man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Why do you bring charges against him,
just because he does not answer all of a man’s questions?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
God does speak, sometimes one way, sometimes another,
but people do not pay attention to it.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
he whispers a revelation into people’s ears,
and he confirms his warnings to them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
in order to turn a man from his course of action
and to suppress a person’s pride.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He spares his life from the pit.
He spares his life from crossing the stream of death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Or a person may be disciplined on his bed by pain
and by continual agony in his bones,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
so that his life makes food disgusting to him,
and he has no appetite for delicious food.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His flesh wastes away and disappears,
and his bones, which were hidden, now stick out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then his soul draws near to destruction,
and his life to those who bring death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If there is a messenger at his side to mediate,
one out of a thousand, to tell a man what is right for him,
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
then his flesh would become more vigorous than it was in his youth.
He would return to days of youthful vitality.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then he would pray to God,
and God would be pleased with him.
With a joyful cry he would see God’s face,
and God would restore his righteousness to the man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the man would turn to people and say,
“I have sinned, and I have perverted what is right,
yet I was not punished as much as I deserved.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
God has redeemed my soul from passing into the pit,
and my life will see the light.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Look, God does all these things with a man—
two times, or even three times—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
to bring back his soul from the pit,
so that light shines on him among the living.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Pay attention, Job. Listen to me.
Be silent, so that I may speak.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If you have anything to say, answer me.
Speak up, for I would be delighted to declare you innocent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If you have nothing to say, listen to me
Be silent, so I may teach you wisdom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elihu resumed his speech and said:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Hear my words, you wise men.
You learned men, pay attention to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It is true that the ear tests words as the mouth tastes food.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So now we should choose for ourselves what is just.
We should determine among ourselves what is good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what Job said:
“I am in the right,
but God has deprived me of justice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Would I lie about what is just for me?
His arrow has inflicted an incurable wound on me,
though I did not rebel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who is like Job?
He drinks down derision against God like water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He travels the road with evildoers,
and he walks with wicked men,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
because he said,
“It is no benefit to a man when he takes pleasure in God.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So then, you men with understanding, listen to me.
I swear that God never does anything wicked.
The Almighty is far from wrongdoing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He repays a man for what he does.
He causes the consequences of his ways to catch up with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
God would absolutely not do anything evil.
The Almighty does not pervert justice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Did anyone put him in charge of the earth?
Did anyone place the whole world under his control?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If God resolved in his heart to recall his spirit and breath to himself,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: all flesh would perish together, and man would return to dust.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But if you have understanding, listen to this.
Hear the sound of my words:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Is it possible that one who hates justice could govern?
Will you condemn the Righteous One, who is mighty?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He says to kings, “You are worthless,”
and tells nobles, “You are evil.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He shows no favoritism to high officials,
and he shows no more regard for the rich than for the poor,
because they are all the work of his hands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In a moment they die, in the middle of the night.
People are shaken, and they pass away.
Even the mighty are taken away effortlessly, without a human hand,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
because God’s eyes are on the ways of a man,
and he sees all his steps.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There is no darkness,
and there is no dark shadow where evildoers can hide,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
for God does not need to investigate further
or to set a time of judgment for a person.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He breaks mighty rulers without further inquiry,
and he sets up others in their place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Because he knows their deeds,
he overthrows them at night,
and they lie crushed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Because of their wickedness,
    he strikes them in plain sight of everyone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He does this because they turned aside from following him,
and they were not wise enough to follow all his ways.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They caused the poor to cry out to God,
so he heard the cry of the afflicted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But if God remains quiet, who can condemn him?
If he hides his face, who can observe him?
But even if he does, he still rules over both nations and individuals,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
to prevent a godless man from ruling,
so that the godless man does not lay snares for the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What if someone says to God,
“I have accepted my punishment.
I will not keep sinning.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Teach me about what I do not see.
If I have done evil, I will not do it again.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Would God then be obligated to repay you on your terms,
when you refuse to repent?
But, Job, it is your decision, not mine.
So tell me what you know.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Men who have understanding say this to me,
and any wise person who listens tells me the same thing:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Job speaks without knowledge,
and his words reveal a lack of understanding.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I wish that Job would be tested to the limit,
because he responds like a wicked man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yes, he even adds rebellion to his sin.
Among us he shows his contempt by clapping his hands,
and he multiplies his words against God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Elihu continued:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do you really think it is right when you say,
“My righteousness is greater than God’s”?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You even say, “What use will this be to me?
How will it profit me more than if I sinned?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I will respond to your words—and to your friends with you!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Look at the heavens and you will see.
Take a good look at the clouds.
They are high above you!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If you have sinned, how does that affect God?
If your rebellious deeds are many, what harm can you do to him?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If you are righteous, what are you giving to him?
What does he receive from your hand?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your wickedness only affects a man like you,
and your righteousness only impacts other people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They cry out because of severe oppression.
They scream for relief from the arm of the powerful.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But no one asks, “Where is God my Maker,
    who provides songs in the night,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
who teaches us more than the wild animals on the earth,
        who makes us wiser than the birds in the sky?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the wicked cry out, but he does not answer,
    because of their arrogant pride.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Certainly God will not listen to an insincere cry,
and the Almighty will not pay attention to it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How much less when you say
    that you do not see him,
    that your case has been presented to him,
    and that you are waiting for him!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Besides that, you say that his anger has not demanded an accounting,
and that he does not fully understand sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Job opens his mouth pointlessly,
and he heaps up words without knowledge.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elihu kept talking and said:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Be patient with me a little longer.
I intend to inform you further,
since I have more to say on God’s behalf.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will provide you with comprehensive knowledge,
and I will justify my Maker.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You can be sure that none of my words are false.
A man with complete knowledge is here with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yes, God is mighty, but he does not despise people.
He is mighty and has great understanding.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He does not keep a wicked man alive,
but he does give justice to the oppressed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He does not turn his eyes away from the righteous.
He seats them on thrones with kings
and exalts them forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But if people are bound in chains,
and they are held captive by cords of affliction,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
he declares to them what they have done—
how arrogantly they have committed rebellious deeds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He opens their ears to accept discipline,
and he tells them to turn back from wickedness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If they listen and serve him,
they will complete their days in prosperity,
and their years will end in pleasure.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But if they do not listen,
they will be overwhelmed by a stream.
They will breathe their last without knowledge.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Godless hearts nourish anger.
They do not cry out for help even when he imprisons them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Their souls die while they are still young,
and they end their lives among the male prostitutes at their shrines.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
God delivers the afflicted by means of their affliction,
and he gets their attention through their suffering.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Certainly he is drawing you out of the jaws of distress
    to a wide-open place, where you will not be hemmed in.
You will be comfortable at your table covered with rich food.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But now you are caught up with the judgment of the wicked,
and judgment and justice have taken hold of you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Watch out, so that no one lures you with luxury.
Do not let a large payment turn you aside.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Can your affluence arrange for your security,
    so that you do not suffer want?
Can even your strongest efforts accomplish that?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not long for night time, when nations vanish from their place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Watch out. Do not turn to evil,
because that is why you have been tested by affliction.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Listen to me. God is exalted in his power.
Who is a teacher like him?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who has dictated his way for him?
Who has said, “You have done wrong”?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Remember that you should praise his work,
    which people have celebrated in song.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All mankind has observed it.
People can look at it from a distance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yes, God is exalted far beyond our comprehension.
The number of his years is beyond investigation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He draws up drops of water from the sea,
and he distills the raindrops to form mist,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
which flow down from the clouds
and pour down abundantly on mankind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Indeed, who understands how the clouds spread out?
Who understands how the thunder rumbles out from his shelter?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Look how he spreads his light all around him,
and he covers the bottom of the sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He uses this to bring judgment on peoples
and to provide abundant food.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
With his hands he grasps the lightning,
and he gives it orders as it advances.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Through the thunder he sounds his war cry.
The herds sense the coming of the rising storm.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When I hear this, my heart races
and leaps from its place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Listen! Listen to the booming thunder of his voice,
to the rumble that goes out from his mouth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He turns it loose across the whole sky,
and his light reaches the ends of the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
After the lightning, a voice roars.
He thunders with his majestic voice.
He does not restrain the lightning.
Then his voice is heard!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
God thunders with his voice in wonderful ways.
He does great things that we do not understand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
To the snow he says, “Fall on the earth.”
To the pouring rain, the torrential downpours of rain,
    he says, “Be strong.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He brings an end to all the work of men’s hands,
    so that they recognize his work.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The wild animals take shelter in their lairs.
They remain in their dens.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A winter wind comes out from its room,
and driving winds bring icy cold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The breath of God produces ice.
The wide surface of the water turns solid.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yes, he loads dark clouds with moisture,
and he fills the clouds with his light.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The clouds swirl around at his direction.
They do whatever he commands them
    over the face of the whole inhabited world.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Whether their purpose is to bring punishment or mercy to the world,
    he makes them achieve their goal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Listen to this, Job! Stand still and recognize the wonders of God!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do you know how God arranges them?
Do you know how he makes his light shine out from his clouds?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do you know how the clouds float in the sky,
    those marvels produced by perfect knowledge?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You, whose clothing is too hot for you
    when the land rests quietly because of the hot south wind,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
can you help him spread out the clouds
    when the sky is as hard as a metal mirror?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Teach us what we should say to him!
We are not able to prepare our case because of the darkness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Should he be notified that I want to speak?
Or would a man who said that be swallowed up?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But no one can look at the sun.
It is too bright when the wind has cleared the sky of the clouds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
God’s golden splendor comes from the north.
God is surrounded by awesome majesty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As for the Almighty, we cannot comprehend him.
He is exalted in power,
but he does not violate justice and great righteousness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Therefore men should revere him,
because he has regard for all those who are wise in heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord responded to Job out of a violent storm. He said:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who is this who spreads darkness over my plans
    with his ignorant words?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Get ready for action like a man!
Then I will ask you questions,
and you will inform me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Where were you when I laid the foundation of the earth?
Tell me, if you understand anything about it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who determined its dimensions?
I am sure you know.
Who stretched out the surveying line over it?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What supports its foundation?
Who set its cornerstone in place,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
when the morning stars sang loud songs together,
        and all the sons of God shouted for joy?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who locked up the sea behind doors
    when it burst out of the womb?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When I clothed the sea with clouds,
when I wrapped it with thick darkness as its swaddling cloths,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
when I broke its power with my decree,
when I locked it up behind barred, double doors,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I said, “You may come this far, but no farther.
Here is the barrier for your proud waves.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Have you ever in all your days given a command to the morning?
Have you ever set a time for the sun to rise,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
so it may grab the earth by its edges
and shake the wicked out of it?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The earth’s shapes become visible like designs impressed on clay,
and its decorations can be seen like those on a garment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Their light is withheld from the wicked,
and an uplifted arm is broken.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Have you ever traveled to the sources of the sea
or walked around in the dark depths of the ocean?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Have the gates of death been revealed to you?
Have you seen the gates of the shadow of death?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do you comprehend the vast expanses of the earth?
Tell me, if you know all this.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How can someone get to the dwelling of light?
Where is the place for darkness?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Could you lead it to its property?
Do you know the way to its house?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You must know that, since you were born before it,
and you have lived for so many days!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Have you visited the warehouses where the snow is kept?
Have you seen the warehouses where the hail is stored?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I have reserved them for troubled times,
for days of battle and war.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What is the way to the place where the lightning divides,
where the east wind is scattered over the earth?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who has excavated a channel for the floodwaters
and a road for the rolling thunder?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They bring rain to lands where no one lives,
to a wilderness without a person in it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The rain satisfies the wilderness and wasteland
and causes the dry ground to produce green plants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Does the rain have a father?
Who is the father of the drops of dew?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Whose womb produces the ice?
Who gives birth to the heavy frost from the sky?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The water is disguised as stone,
and the surface of the deep is trapped under ice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Can you bind the chains of the Pleiades,
or loosen the belt of Orion?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Can you lead out the constellations at the right season
and guide the Bear with her cubs?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do you know the laws that govern the skies?
Can you establish God’s rule on earth?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Can you raise your voice to the clouds,
so that a flood of water submerges you?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Can you unleash the lightning bolts,
so that they come and say to you, “Here we are”?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who has placed wisdom in the human heart
and given understanding to the mind?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who has the wisdom to count the clouds
and to empty the water jars of the sky,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
when the loose dust has been poured into molds to harden,
and the clods of dirt are cemented together?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Can you hunt prey for a lioness?
Can you satisfy the appetite of the young lions,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
when they crouch in their dens,
or they lie in wait in the thicket?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who prepares its provisions for the raven,
when its young are screaming to God,
while they thrash around in the nest waiting for food?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do you know the time when the antelope on the cliffs gives birth?
Do you keep watch over the doe as she is in labor?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do you count how many months they carry their young?
Do you know when it is time for them to give birth?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They crouch down.
They give birth to their fawns.
Their labor pains are over.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Their young are lively and live in the open countryside.
They go out, and they do not return to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who set the wild donkey free?
Who untied the restraints on the onager?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I have given it the wasteland as its home,
the salt flats as its dwelling place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It brays at the commotion in a town.
It does not listen to the shouting of the driver.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It explores the mountains as its pasture,
while it searches for anything green.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Is a wild ox willing to serve you?
Will it spend the night at your manger?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Can you lead the wild ox down a furrow with a rope?
Will it work the fields in the valleys behind you?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Will you depend on it because it is so strong?
Will you rely on it to labor for you?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Will you trust it to return your seed grain
and to bring it to your threshing floor?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The wings of a screeching ostrich flap wildly,
but they do not have feathers and plumage like a stork’s.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She leaves her eggs on the ground.
She keeps them warm in the dust.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She forgets that a foot may crush them,
or a wild animal may trample them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She is hard-hearted toward her children.
It is as if they were not hers.
It does not bother her if her labor is for nothing,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
because God made her forget wisdom,
and he has not given her any understanding.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But as soon as she jumps up to run,
she laughs at the horse and the rider.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Did you give strength to the horse?
Did you clothe its neck with a flowing mane?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Did you give it the ability to jump like a locust?
Its snorting and neighing are frightening.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It paws at the ground in the valley.
It rejoices in its strength.
It goes out to meet the weapons of war.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
It laughs at danger and is not afraid.
It does not turn away from the sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A quiver rattles against it.
A spear and a javelin flash.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Shaking with excitement, it swallows up ground.
It doesn’t just stand there when the ram’s horn sounds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As often as the horn sounds, it neighs and snorts!
From a distance it smells the battle,
the thunder of the commanders and the war cries.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Did you teach the hawk how to soar,
as it spreads out its wings to the south?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Is it at your command that the eagle flies high
and makes its nest in a lofty place?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
On a rocky cliff it settles down to spend the night,
on a pinnacle of rock in a mountain stronghold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
From there it spies its food.
Its eyes spot it far away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Its young ones drink up the blood.
Wherever the carcasses are—there it is.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord responded to Job and said:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Will the one who makes charges against the Almighty
    dare to correct him?
The one who accuses God should make his case!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Job answered the Lord and said:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
No, I am insignificant.
How could I reply to you?
I will put my hand over my mouth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I spoke once, but I cannot defend it.
Twice, but I will not go any further.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord answered Job from the violent storm. He said:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Get ready for action like a man!
Then I will ask you questions,
and you will inform me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Will you really deny that I am just?
Will you convict me, so that you can be acquitted?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do you have an arm like God’s arm?
Does your voice thunder like his?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Go ahead, please. Adorn yourself with dignity and honor.
Clothe yourself with splendor and majesty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Pour out your overflowing anger.
Look at every proud man and bring him low.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Look at every proud man and humble him.
Trample the wicked where they stand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Bury them all together in the dust.
Cover their faces in the hidden place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then I will praise you
and admit that your right hand can save you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Take a look at Behemoth,
    which I made just as I made you.
He eats grass like cattle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Would you look at the power of his hips
and the strength of the muscles of his belly!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He stiffens his tail like a cedar.
The tendons of his thighs are tight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His bones are tubes of bronze.
His skeleton is like bars of iron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He stands at the head of God’s creatures,
but his Maker draws near with his sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yes, the mountains carry their floodwaters to him.
All the wild animals play there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He lies under the lotus plants,
hidden among the reeds in the marsh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The lotus plants cover him with their shadows.
Poplars by the stream surround him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The river rages, but he is not frightened.
He remains calm even if the Jordan bursts into his mouth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Can people capture him by his eyes?
Can they pierce his nose with a hook?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Can you pull out Leviathan with a fishhook?
Can you tie down his tongue with a rope?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Can you put a reed in his nose
or pierce his jaw with a hook?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Will he keep asking for your favor
or speak tender words to you?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Will he sign a contract with you
so that you keep him as your servant forever?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Can you play with him like a bird?
Can you put him on a leash for your girls?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do the merchants barter for Leviathan’s meat?
Do they divide it up with the other tradesmen?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Can you fill his hide with harpoons
and his head with fishing spears?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If you lay your hand on him,
you will never forget the battle and won’t do it again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Listen! Any hope you have of overcoming him is unfounded.
Wouldn’t you be knocked down by the mere sight of him?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
No one is fierce enough to risk stirring him up.
Who then can stand before me?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who can confront me and demand that I repay him?
Everything under the whole sky belongs to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will tell about the parts of his body.
I will describe his power and his beautiful design.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who can strip off his outer covering?
Who can touch his double layer of armor?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who dares to open the doors to his mouth,
    which is surrounded with terrifying teeth?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His back is like rows of shields,
    which are tightly joined together.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They are so close together not even a breath of air
can pass between them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They are fastened to each other,
so they stick together and cannot be separated.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His snorts are flashes of light.
His eyes are like the eyelids of dawn.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Blazing torches come out of his mouth.
Sparks of fire shoot out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Smoke pours out from his nostrils
    like a pot boiling over a reed fire.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His breath sets coals on fire,
and flames come out of his mouth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Strength dwells in his neck.
Despair dances ahead of him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The folds of his flesh are compact,
solid and immovable.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His heart is as hard as rock,
as hard as a lower millstone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When he rises up, the mighty are afraid.
When he thrashes around, they retreat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If someone strikes him with a sword, it has no effect.
Neither do spears, arrows, or javelins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
To him iron is like straw;
bronze is like rotten wood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Arrows do not make him flee.
To him sling stones are like chaff;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
clubs are like stubble.
He laughs at the shaking of a javelin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His underbelly is like sharp pieces of broken pottery.
It leaves marks in the mud like a threshing sledge.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He makes the depths boil like a cooking pot.
He makes the sea like a cauldron of ointment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He leaves a shiny wake behind him.
The deep looks like a white-haired man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There is nothing at all like him on earth,
a creature without fear.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He looks down on everything that is lofty.
He is king over every proud creature!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Job responded to the Lord. He said:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I know that you can do all things.
No purpose of yours can be thwarted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You asked, “Who is this who spreads darkness over my plans
    with his ignorant words?”
I have made statements about things I did not understand,
things too wonderful for me to know.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You said, “Listen now and I will speak.
I will ask you questions, and you will inform me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My ear heard about you.
Now my eyes see you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So I despise myself.
I repent in dust and ashes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After the Lord had spoken these words to Job, he said to Eliphaz the Temanite, “My anger burns against you and your two friends, because none of you have spoken correctly about me, as my servant Job did.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So now, take seven bulls and seven rams for yourselves, go to my servant Job, and offer up a whole burnt offering for yourselves. My servant Job will pray for you, so that I will look upon him with favor and not deal with you on the basis of your foolishness, for none of you have spoken correctly about me, as my servant Job did.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Eliphaz the Temanite, Bildad the Shuhite, and Zophar the Na’amathite went and did as the Lord had told them, and the Lord looked on Job with favor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord restored Job’s fortunes, after he had prayed on behalf of his friends. The Lord gave Job twice as much of everything as he had before.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all his brothers and sisters and all his acquaintances came to Job. They dined with him in his house, and they showed him sympathy and comforted him concerning the tragedy that the Lord had brought on him. Each of them gave him one qesitah of silver and one gold ring.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord blessed the last part of Job’s life more than the first part, so he had fourteen thousand sheep, six thousand camels, one thousand yoke of oxen, and one thousand female donkeys.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had seven sons and three daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He named his first daughter Jemimah, the second Keziah, and the third Keren Happuk.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the whole land there were no women as beautiful as the daughters of Job. Their father gave them an inheritance among their brothers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, Job lived one hundred forty years and saw his sons and their children to the fourth generation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Job died, old and fulfilled by a long life.
verses.speaker: Narrator
